Comments_List: The senior thesis project has taught me a lot in how to go about researching a topic and crafting an argument around the pieces of information I find. It has definitely shown me how difficult it can be to put together a history of a disease during a specific time frame and trying to reconstruct what the public attitudes were toward health officials at the time.
My thesis advisor is Simone Browne, and I developed new ways of thinking about and approaching my topic of IBM and surveillance.
This isn't really a course, but both my senior project advisor and Professor Roberts have been helpful during this process.
I learned how to do a long research assignment. I learned to use Yale Library's various databases. I learned a lot of history around my specific topic.
Independent thesis work, up to oneself to stay on track.

It's okay. The deadlines are spaced out enough, but the assignments (especially towards the beginning and middle) seem a bit repetitive. I would have preferred to have more of a heads-up junior year and perhaps some more time (in junior or senior year) to begin exploring topics. Other than that, I really enjoyed working with my advisor, but the "class" is pretty unstructured/independent so I don't know what else to comment on.
The senior paper is mandatory for HSHM students.
